The highest over-limit ratio of FBs was 12.12% (folium and cortex), followed the over-limit ratios in flos (6.67%), fructus and semen (6.67%), and radix and rhizoma (5.56%), as shown in Fig. 1 H and Supplemental File: Dataset S3. 3.2 Diversity and composition of fungal communities in herbal medicines A total of 14,800,926 high-quality reads were identified from 240 herbal medicine samples, ranging from 46,397 reads to 73,473 reads (Supplemental File: Dataset S4). Chao 1 varied among the herbal medicines, ranging from 243 to 2663 (Supplemental File: Fig. S1A ). The range of the Shannon index was 0.69–4.75 (Supplemental File: Fig. S1B ). Ascomycota (80.20% of sequences) and Basidiomycota (8.02%) were the most abundant phyla (Supplemental File: Dataset S5). The most predominant genus was Aspergillus (43.77%), followed by Fusarium (5.17%), Cladosporium (4.46%), Alternaria (3.69%), Penicillium (2.85%), and Xeromyces (2.46%), as shown in Supplemental File: Dataset S6. The diversity and composition of the fungal communities in different medicinal types were different. In general, the Chao 1 and Shannon indices in the flos group were higher than those of the radix and rhizoma, fructus and semen, folium and cortex, and herba and others ( Fig. 2 A–B). The number of common and unique OTUs in the five groups is shown in the Venn diagram ( Fig. 2 C). Overall, 1,497, 206, 551, 433, and 156 OTUs were obtained from radix and rhizoma, flos, fructus and semen, folium and cortex, and herba and others, respectively. NMDS analyses based on unweighted dissimilarities showed that different medicinal types markedly affected the composition of fungal communities (R = 0.12, P = 0.002, ANOSIM test analysis; Fig. 2 D). Herein, fungal communities in different medicinal types were analyzed at the phylum and genus levels ( Fig. 2 E–F and Supplemental File: Figs. S2–S3 and Tables S4–S5 ). At the phylum level, Ascomycota and Basidiomycota displayed significant compartment specificity ( P < 0.05). The average relative abundances of Ascomycota in herba and others and fructus and semen groups were significantly higher than those in the other groups. By contrast, the average relative abundances of Basidiomycota in the flos and radix and rhizoma groups were significantly higher than those in the other groups. At the genus level, the average relative abundances of Aspergillus in folium and cortex and herba and others groups were significantly higher than those in the other groups. The average relative abundances of Cladosporium , Fusarium , and Alternaria were significantly enriched in the flos groups, compared with those in the other groups. The average relative abundances of Penicillium and Xeromyces were significantly enriched in the fructus and semen and radix and rhizoma groups, compared with those in the other groups. After the mycotoxin content in each herbal medicine sample was determined, the diversity and composition of fungal communities in mycotoxin-free, -contaminated, and -excessive groups were compared. In general, the Chao 1 and Shannon indices in the mycotoxin-free group were higher than those of mycotoxin-excessive and -contaminated groups ( Fig. 3 A–B). Venn profiles revealed 4068 OTUs shared by three groups, and the mycotoxin-free, -contaminated, and -excessive groups had 354, 1919, and 594 unique OTUs, respectively ( Fig. 3 C). NMDS analyses based on unweighted dissimilarities found that mycotoxin content significantly affected the composition of the fungal communities (R = 0.24, P = 0.007, ANOSIM test analysis; Fig. 3 D). At the phylum level, the average relative abundances of Ascomycota, Blastocladiomycota, Mucoromycota, and Olpidiomycota in the mycotoxin-excessive group were significantly higher than those in the mycotoxin-contaminated and -free groups ( Fig. 3 E and Supplemental File: Table S6 ). In addition, the average relative abundances of Basidiomycota and Chytridiomycota in the mycotoxin-contaminated group were significantly higher than those in the mycotoxin-excessive and -free groups. At the genus level, the average relative abundances of Aspergillus , Fusarium , Penicillium , and Xeromyces in the mycotoxin-excessive group were significantly higher than those in mycotoxin-contaminated and -free groups ( Fig. 3 F and Supplemental File: Table S7 ). The average relative abundances of Cladosporium , Alternaria , Plectosphaerella , and Vishniacozyma in the mycotoxin-contaminated group were significantly higher than those in the mycotoxin-excessive and -free groups. 3.3 Spearman's correlation analysis of fungal abundance and mycotoxin content The correlations of fungal abundance and mycotoxin content were calculated using Spearman's correlation, and the results showed that the abundances of 10, 5, and 11 fungi were significantly correlated with AF, OT, and FB content, respectively ( P < 0.05; Fig. 4 and Supplemental File: Dataset S7). In particular, AF content was significantly and positively correlated with the abundances of Alternaria , Aspergillus , Aureobasidium , Debaryomyces , Fusarium , Monilia , Phoma , Strigula , and Filobasidium (R > 0.5, P < 0.05). In addition, OT content was significantly and positively correlated with the abundances of Alternaria , Aureobasidium , Didymella , and Penicillium (R > 0.5, P < 0.05). Moreover, FB content was significantly and positively correlated with the abundances of Alternaria , Cyberlindnera , Fusarium , Paraconiothyrium , Penicillium , Phoma , Wickerhamomyces , Naganishia , Rhodosporidiobolus , and Rhodotorula (R > 0.6, P < 0.05). 3.4 Isolation and identification of fungi producing mycotoxins in herbal medicines A total of 323 isolates were isolated from herbal medicines, and 20 fungal strains were obtained after identification ( Table 1 and Supplemental File: Dataset S8). The most predominant genus was Aspergillus (283, 87.62%), followed by Penicillium (9, 2.79%), Didymella (8, 2.48%), Aureobasidium (6, 1.86%), and Mucor (4, 1.24%). In the 283 Aspergillus species recovered, A. niger (71.21%) was the dominant species, followed by A. flavus (10.84%), A. costaricensis (3.72%), A. terreus (0.93%), A. urmiensis (0.31%), A. nidulans (0.31%), and A. versicolor (0.31%). However, the Penicillium genus had two species, P. limosum (1.24%) and P. chrysogenum (0.93%). The morphology and microstructures of the partial primary strains are shown in Supplemental File: Fig. S4 . The Aspergillus and Penicillium were the predominant genera in our culturable fungi, similar to our sequencing results. The analysis of potential mycotoxin-producing fungi showed that mycotoxins were detected in three strains ( A. flavus , A. niger , and A. ochraceus ; Fig. 5 ). For A. niger , the colony grew rapidly and was initially white before turning black and plush; the conidium head was brown-black and radiating, the meristem varied in length, the apical capsule was spherical, the pedicel was double, and the conidia were brown and spherical ( Fig. 5 A). The A. flavus colony grew rapidly and had a loose structure and pale-yellow surface. The mycelium was composed of various complex branching hyphae, and the vegetative hyphae were separated. In addition, the mycelium formed long and rough conidia and had flask-shaped or nearly spherical apical sacs at the top, and various pedicels with spherical conidia with rough surfaces were observed ( Fig. 5 B). The A. ochraceus colony grew rapidly and was flat, and velvety. The conidium head was brown and black, the apical capsule was spherical and lagger, and the conidia were spherical ( Fig. 5 C). After being cultured at 25 °C (180 rpm) for 7 days, AFB1 (206.75 μg/mL), AFB2 (3.31 μg/mL), and AFG2 (4.34 μg/mL) were simultaneously detected in one strain of A. flavus ; hence, OTA was detected in the strains of A. ochraceus (228.27 μg/mL) and A. niger (500.24 μg/mL), as shown in Fig. 5 D and E. 3.5 Establishment and application of rapid detection method for toxigenic fungi in herbal medicines Multiple real-time fluorescent PCR was established to facilitate the simultaneous detection of mycotoxin-producing fungi isolated from herbal medicines. Primers specific for regulatory genes involved in AFs ( aflR , omt-1 , nor1 , and ver-1 ) and OTA ( aoksl ) biosynthesis were assayed in Aspergillus ( Fig. 6 A). The amplification products of aflR and aoksl were obtained from A. flavus , A. ochraceus , and A. niger and displayed positive signals when corresponding gene primers were used. These positive signals indicated the potential uses of these products in AF and OTA production. Hence, the specificity of the developed multiple real-time fluorescent PCR was conﬁrmed; it showed good performance in discriminating among the tested species and between mycotoxin-producing and nonproducing strains. The established multiple real-time fluorescent PCR was applied to detect the mycobiota of herbal medicines, and 164 samples were tested for the presence of genes involved in the biosynthesis of mycotoxins ( Fig. 6 B–F and Supplemental File: Dataset S9). A total of 110 (67.07%) herbal medicines were positive for aflR signals with concentrations from 5.92 copies to 2900 copies, indicating the presence of aflatoxigenic strains ( Fig. 6 B–C). AF content was tested at 0.03–27.30 μg/kg ( Fig. 6 D). A high relevance (R 2 = 0.9988) was observed between the aflR gene copies and AF content ( Fig. 6 E). In addition, the aoksl gene was detected in 61 herbal medicines from 15.7 copies up to 288 copies, indicating that 37.20% of herbal medicine samples were positive for OTA-producing strains ( Fig. 6 B–C). OTA content was tested at 0.02–2.76 μg/kg ( Fig. 6 D), and an excellent correlation (R 2 = 0.9982) was obtained between the gene aoksl copies and OTA content ( Fig. 6 F). 4 Discussion A total of 240 herbal medicine samples were analyzed for mycotoxins contamination. Approximately 62.92%, 36.25%, and 64.17% of the samples were contaminated with AFs, OTs, and FBs, respectively. A previous study showed that 50 out of 60 (83.3% of incidence) herbal medicines were contaminated with mycotoxins at concentrations ranging from 1.7 μg/kg to 48.0 μg/kg ( Han et al., 2012 ). AFs are potent mutagens and carcinogens, and 15.5% of traditional Chinese medicine samples were positive for AFs with concentrations of up to 290.8 μg/kg; 5.71% of the positive samples exceeded the proposed limits ( Liu et al., 2012 ). OTA exerts nephrotoxic, teratogenic, neurotoxic, and hepatotoxic effects (Petzinger et al., 2000). Eight (26.7%) samples were contaminated with OTA at concentrations ranging from 9.85 μg/kg to 125 μg/kg ( Ahmad et al., 2014 ). FB contamination in medicinal plants has been reported, and 75% of samples were found contaminated with FB1 with an average concentration of 0.315 μg/kg (Karbancioglu-Güler et al., 2009). More than 50% of traditional Chinese medicine samples were contaminated with FBs (0.58–88.95 μg/kg); 94.4%, 77.8%, and 33.3% of the samples were contaminated with FB1, FB2, and FB3, respectively ( Han et al., 2010b ). The maximum limits of 10 μg/kg for total AFs in some herbal medicines have been set by the Chinese Pharmacopeia, OTs are regulated at 20 μg/kg in the European Pharmacopeia, and FBs are regulated at 1000 μg/kg in the European Union Commission Regulation ( CPC, 2020 ; EP, 20 11; EC, 2007). In our paper, 24.17%, 3.33%, and 6.25% of samples exceeded content of AFs (10 μg/kg), OTs (20 μg/kg), and FBs (1000 μg/kg). A previous study showed that 10 samples (5.71%) exceeded the AF content (10 μg/kg) in 174 herbal medicine samples ( Romagnoli et al., 2007 ). Some medicinal plants and related products sold commercially may be contaminated with high levels of mycotoxins because of the lack of official legislation. To guarantee drug safety and consumer interests, official legislation on the maximum limits of common mycotoxins in herbal medicines should be formulated and implemented. Seeds had a higher level of FB contamination (90%) than rhizomes and roots, grasses and leaves, and flowers in the herbal medicine samples ( Siddique et al., 2013 ). Our results showed that the over-limit ratios of mycotoxins were higher in the radix and rhizoma, fructus and semen, and folium and cortex than the over-limit ratio in herba and others. Herbal medicines are rich in starch and oil, which might promote mycotoxin production ( Ying et al., 2016 ). In particular, the contamination levels of some samples (i.e., Rhei Radix et Rhizoma, Polygini Multiflori Radix, Angelicae Dahuricae Radix, Corni Fructus, and Amomi Fructus) were notable, as they had high sugar, fat, or starch content (Zain et al., 2011). The different mycotoxin levels in herbal medicines results from fungal growth rates, which were affected by some factors, such as storage temperature and moisture level ( Liu et al., 2012 ). In other words, herbal medicines are easily contaminated by all kinds of molds that produce various mycotoxins, and the process is complicated by intrinsic (i.e., chemical composition) and extrinsic environmental (i.e., temperature and moisture) factors. Contamination not only affects the quality of herbal medicines and resulting in enormous financial loss but also influences the safety and effectiveness of herbal medicines, posing potential threats to human health. Therefore, herbs should be dried as soon as possible after harvesting, and appropriate measures, such as the “antagonistic storage” method based on the “couplet medicine” technique should be performed during the storage of herbal medicines ( Ying et al., 2016 ). The “couplet medicine” technique is based on the principle of “protecting herbal medicines with other herbal medicines.” Two kinds of herbal medicines are stored together and prevent mildew while competing with each other, exhibiting no obvious changes in color, smell, and quality. As a green, safe, and economic strategy for preserving herbal medicines, the “antagonistic storage” method is based on the above mode and principle of “couplet medicine” technique to protect herbal medicines from being moldy. Mycotoxins are toxic secondary metabolites produced by fungi, such as Aspergillus , Penicillium , Fusarium , and Alternaria (Zain et al., 2011). Approximately 92% of medicinal herbs and spices collected from India are contaminated by fungi, and 47% exceeded the permissible limits of the WHO (Aiko et al., 2016). High-throughput sequencing is a potential approach for investigating the fungal contamination in herbal medicines and ensuring drug efficacy ( Luo et al., 2019 ). We applied high-throughput sequencing to study fungal contamination in 240 herbal medicines. Our sequencing results showed that the richness and diversity of fungal communities varied among the herbal medicines. Ascomycota and Basidiomycota were the most predominant phyla, consistent to a previous study ( Jiang et al., 2020 ). The most predominant genus was Aspergillus , followed by Fusarium , Cladosporium , Alternaria , Penicillium , and Xeromyces in our herbal medicines; a similar phenomenon was shown in previous studies ( Yu et al., 2020 ). In Ziziphi Spinosae Semen samples, Ascomycota, Aspergillus , Candida , and Wallemia were the dominant fungi ( Guo et al., 2018 ). In the Cassiae Semen samples, Ascomycota, Aspergillus , Cladosporium , and Penicillium were the prevailing fungi . These studies showed that Ascomycota, Aspergillus , and Penicillium were the most common contaminants and potentially produce mycotoxins. Meanwhile, difference in fungal community among the five groups with different medicinal types was found. Especially, the abundances of P en icillium and Xeromyces were significantly enriched in fructus and semen and radix and rhizoma groups, which had high sugar, fat, or starch content. The chemical composition of herbal medicines might be the main factor influencing the fungal microbiota. Furthermore, difference in fungal community among the three groups (mycotoxin-free, -contaminated, and -excessive groups) was observed. The Chao1 and Shannon indices of the fungal microbiome in the mycotoxin-free group were higher than those of the mycotoxin-excessive and -contaminated groups. This result was consistent with the findings of other studies and indicated that fungal microbiome diversity was reduced in the presence of mycotoxin contamination ( Ding et al., 2015 ; Yuan et al., 2018 ). In a previous study, difference in fungal diversity between aflatoxin-contaminated and -free Platycladi Semen samples was observed, and mycotoxin-producing fungi associated with mycotoxin content was found in Platycladi Semen ( Yu et al., 2020 ). Spearman's correlation results showed that fungal abundance (e.g., Aspergillus Fusarium , and Penicillium ) was significantly correlated with the content of mycotoxins (e.g., AFs, OTA, and FBs). Notably, the presence of these potential mycotoxin-producing fungi is a necessary prerequisite for mycotoxin contamination. In addition, Aspergillus , Fusarium , Penicillium , and Alternaria spp. were the most frequently detected genera contaminating food and herbal medicines and contained the majority of mycotoxin producers ( Zheng et al., 2017 ). AFs were produced by Aspergillus (Bennett et al., 2003), OTA was mainly produced by Penicillium and Aspergillus spp. ( Ashiq et al., 2014 ), and FBs were mainly produced by various Fusarium spp. under diverse environmental conditions (Karbancioglu-Güler et al., 2009). Fungi were isolated from the herbal medicines to verify potential mycotoxin producers. The results showed that Aspergillus and Penicillium were the most predominant genera, similar to our high-throughput sequencing results. A. niger , A. flavus , P. limosum , and P. chrysogenum were the dominant species. In medicinal herbs, two distinct fungi classes were noted: field fungi (e.g., Fusarium and Alternaria ) and storage fungi (e.g., Aspergillus and Penicillium ; Sudharsan et al., 2017 ). The predominant mycoflora isolated in the present study was composed of storage fungi. Potential toxigenic fungi, such as A. niger , A. flavus , and Penicillium spp . , were the predominant molds isolated in some herbal medicines, and 31% of the strains were toxigenic ( Ahmad et al., 2014 ). In addition, A. flavus was positive for AFs, and A. ochraceus and A. niger were positive for OTA. AFs were produced by Aspergillus , particularly A. flavus and A. parasiticus (Bennett et al., 2003). OTA is mainly produced by P. nordicum , P. verrucosum , P. chrysogenum , A. niger , and A. ochraceus under diverse environmental conditions ( Ashiq et al., 2014 ). FBs are mainly produced by various species of Fusarium , including F. proliferatum and F. verticillioides (Karbancioglu-Güler et al., 2009). Although a large of Fusarium stains are FB producers, none of the Fusarium stains in our study produced FBs. This result needs to be examined further. Given that herbal medicines are easily contaminated by mycobiota before harvest and storage, the high safety of herbal medicines needs to be ensured because of their importance. The multiplex real-time PCR results showed that A. flavus and A. ochraceus harbored AF and OTA biosynthesis genes ( aflR and aoksl ); hence, the probability of the production of a particular toxin may be predicted according to the presence or absence of a gene-amplification product ( Ayanbimpe et al., 2009 ). The results of the established multiplex real-time PCR showed that 110 (67.07%) and 61 (37.20%) herbal medicines were contaminated by AF- and OTA-producing strains, respectively. The results were validated, and an excellent correlation was found between gene copies and mycotoxin content (R 2 = 0.99). The established multiplex real-time PCR analysis facilitated the rapid screening of herbal medicines with fungal contamination. 5 Conclusions A globalized and standardized strategy for monitoring extrinsic hazardous materials, such as mycotoxins, should be developed to ensure the safety of herbal medicines and their benefits to human health. This paper provided the contamination status of fungi and mycotoxins in herbal medicines and established a rapid method for detecting toxigenic fungi. Herein, the prevalent contamination phenomenon of mycotoxins (AFs, OTs, and FBs) and potential toxigenic fungi ( Aspergillus , Fusarium , and Cladosporium ) was observed. A. flavus harbored the AF-synthesis gene aflR , and A. ochraceus and A. niger harbored the OTA-synthesis gene aoksl . With aflR and aoksl genes, multiplex real-time PCR was established for the rapid and accurate detection of AF- and OTA-producing fungi. This work established a rapid method for detecting toxigenic fungi in herbal medicines and providing early risk warning about mycotoxin contamination in herbal medicines.
